videos.transcript: American Airlines has promised Wall Street and travelers that 2026 will be its turnaround year. [music] It's been trailing its US competitors Delta Airlines and United Airlines and profits and reliability by a wide margin and has fallen behind in the race for premium air travel. >> The customer experience is really what matters. And there is the issue goes back to basic tenants of what kind of a business you want to run. And if you don't run a reliable business, you don't get repeat customers. [music] American stock is down over the last 12 months while other major US airlines have posted [music] gains. So the pressure is on for CEO Robert Isim. >> We were on track really like what we saw in October in terms of bookings [music] on track to have a a really solid turnaround in terms of our fourth quarter performance. [music] Government shutdown hit us. It hit us harder than than others. We're more domestically focused. We've seen bookings return. First three weeks of this year, our best bookings uh on record. And as we come and take a look at this this year 2026, [music] we're returning to solid profitability. >> The airline flew a similar number of passengers [music] and flights as its close competitors last year, but its profit was a tiny fraction of what United and Delta reported. Its net margins were significantly narrower, too.

videos.title: Inside The Crisis Facing U.S. Auto Giants
videos.description:
CNBC examines the high-stakes decisions transforming the U.S. auto industry.
Cars once promised independence and transportation for all Americans. Now, they are a luxury product that cost about $50,000, nearly 30% higher than just a few years ago. Affordable vehicles, especially those below the price of $20,000, have nearly disappeared. And while Automakers pulled in record profits in 2023, slim margins combined with deep investments into EV batteries, software and other technology is making it hard to produce cars much cheaper. Chinese automakers can, but they're impeded by tariffs and rules. Insiders say that is just a bandage - automakers need to compete.

The HEMI name is one of the strongest names in the history of the brands collectively known under the Chrysler and MOPAR names - Jeep, Dodge, Chrysler, and the RAM Trucks brand. The 5.7 liter HEMI V8 was especially important to RAM, as the company learned the hard way. Dropping the engine in an effort to get greener cost the company at least 30,000 customers annually. Sales fell every quarter after the company replaced the HEMI with the smaller Hurricane inline 6-cylinderâ€“even though that engine has higher horsepower and torque numbers than the HEMI. So RAM buckled and brought back the engine. The whole saga is another example of the kinds of trouble the American Chrysler brands faced after they merged with Peugeot to form Stellantis.

The Chrysler name was once one of the most recognizable in the American automotive industry. A bankruptcy and two mergers later, it is just a tiny brand some fear will face extinction. Its lineup has been whittled down to two models of one vehicle â€“ a minivan. But its brand CEO, Christine Feuell, says Chrysler is here to stay and more vehicles are coming soon.

This CNBC Marathon investigates the forces reshaping the U.S. auto industry.

Chapters:
00:00: Introduction
01:05: Why American Cars Are So Expensive (Published November 2024)
14:49: Why Chrysler Has Nearly Disappeared (Published January 2025)
27:24: Why RAM Brought Back The V-8 Engine (Published July 2025)

And what I drive today so I can compare and contrast. That's about 30,000 units a year automatically that I would have lost. And with loyalty running in 7,580% of the truck segment, you don't want to lose any of those customers. Kuniskis expects about 40% of Ram buyers sooner or later to settle on the HEMI. That's a lot higher than the Ford F-150 V8. Take rate of about 25%, but slightly lower than GM's, which Kuniskis attributes to the fact that apart from a diesel. Gm offers a choice of two V8's or a four cylinder Ford F-150. Buyers can swap in a V8 for free on most versions of the truck, Ram buyers have to pay an extra $1,200 unless they get the high end Limited or Longhorn trims. Kuniskis thinks a lot of people will choose the HEMI anyway. HEMI is not really just a V8. It's kind of a brand in and of itself. It's it's become a thing. And Ram isn't giving up on the hurricane. The reality is, as attached as some buyers are to V8, customers are choosing smaller engines. Toyota has already dropped its V8 from the tundra lineup with less pushback. You're gonna want to see what the new engine is compared to what you're used to, so you're going to want to drive them both. It's all about the choice. It's not about one versus the other. It's about having the choice. It's also not giving up on electric. Ram is planning two new EV trucks, one fully electric and another with a gas burning generator. Kind of typecast with, you know, I'm the HEMI guy, I'm the supercharger guy, I'm the Hellcat guy, all that kind of stuff. And it's it's weird to hear you talk about electric vehicles. A lot of times people that bash electric vehicles have never driven one, um, electric cars, they have their faults. There's no question they have their faults, but they are fantastic. They they can have electric vehicles. I won't buy one. Uh, I'm an ex Tesla employee. I've never owned an electric car, but if Dodge really wants to sell Vehicles. They have to sell customizable cars that scream drive me! We are in the very early days. 500 mile range, lighter solid state batteries, inductive charging, sufficient infrastructure and prices that are comparable to gas engines. Kuniskis is confident all these will happen. When you get there, you will get mass adoption. The problem is we tried to force mass adoption before we got there. The car displaced the horse because it was better. The electric car is going to be better. We just have a lot of challenges in the industry that we have to overcome first, and and we will overcome them. We have to, because as an industry, we've invested about a half $1 trillion in this.

The gloves are coming off in the high-stakes rivalry between OpenAI and Anthropic as both companies race towards potential IPOs in late-2026. OpenAIâ€™s move to introduce ads into ChatGPT setting off sniping between executives on both sides and a multi-million dollar Super Bowl ad promising Anthropic will not have ads in its Claude chatbot. This tension traces back to a 2020 split over AI safety between OpenAI and Anthropic co-founder Dario Amodei, but it has evolved into a brutal fight for the lucrative enterprise market where Anthropicâ€™s Claude has seen viral success in recent months. The companies have raised hundreds of billions of dollars in the private markets, and both are poised to IPO with historic valuations. What The Endangerment Finding Rollback Means For Automakers

videos.transcript:
The Trump administration 
just repealed a scientific finding that provides the 
legal basis for the EPA to regulate climate pollution. The 2009 endangerment 
finding concluded that six greenhouse gases threaten 
public health and welfare by exacerbating extreme 
weather. The determination required 
the federal government to regulate carbon dioxide, 
methane, and other greenhouse gases 
that are generated by the burning of oil, 
gas, and coal. It's important because it 
enables EPA to do its job to adopt standards that cuts 
this harmful pollution and protects Americans. The reversal will remove the 
regulatory requirements for motor vehicle emissions and 
rollback related compliance programs and credit 
provisions. It will also open the door 
for a future repeal of power plant regulations. This action will eliminate 
over $1.3 trillion of regulatory costs and help 
bring car prices tumbling down dramatically. For Americans, 
this means more pollution. As much as 18 billion tons 
of additional climate altering pollution. It means 
higher costs, means Americans will spend 
up to $1.4 trillion more in fuel to power these less 
efficient and higher polluting vehicles. And for 
automakers, it means removing a stable, 
predictable regulatory framework that has allowed 
automakers to invest, to innovate and to compete 
globally. The rule change will have 
the biggest impact on the auto industry. The 
transportation sector is the largest contributor of 
greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S., accounting for 
about 28% of the country's total emissions. Federal officials said that 
the reversal could save $2,400 per vehicle, 
according to the Wall Street Journal. But regulatory 
uncertainty can make it difficult for companies to 
plan and can threaten business stability. Things 
in the automotive industry work on like five, 
seven, sometimes even ten year timelines. You need to be able to plan 
things out, and when regulations change 
like this, it can really disrupt a lot 
of the plans that are already in place. In a statement, 
Ford Motor Company told CNBC that they have consistently 
advocated for a single, stable national standard 
that aligns with customer choice, the market, 
societal benefit and American job growth. Removing these protections, 
the endangerment finding clean vehicle standards, 
removing consumer rebates that support clean vehicles 
makes it harder to compete in a world that's globally 
competitive, where we see companies 
racing ahead to build the technologies of tomorrow 
that save people money and cut pollution. The other issue is that 
automakers work across all different kinds of markets, 
and if those markets have different regulations, 
then they have to keep adjusting their product 
strategy in different places to suit the local 
regulations. The more consistent the 
rules are across all the markets where an automaker 
might operate, the better it is for them, 
because it gives them an opportunity to do everything 
consistently and achieve those economies of scale 
that help them get profitability. It remains to 
be seen how the auto industry will respond to the 
new rule. A lot of the automakers that 
operate in the United States operate in several different 
countries, and a lot of those countries 
still have emissions regulations that are quite 
strict. And so if Ford or GM or 
Toyota or whoever else wants to sell vehicles in Europe 
or Asia or Latin America or somewhere else in the world, 
and the country that they want to sell those vehicles 
in still has really strict emissions regulations, 
they might end up just deciding that they want to 
keep their vehicles pretty efficient across their 
entire fleet so that they're not making different 
vehicles for every different market. In the absence of 
emissions regulations at the federal level, 
states may step up and enact their own legislation. States have played a very 
important role in reducing climate pollution, 
including from vehicles. California has adopted 
standards that have cut pollution, saved consumers 
money. And so the role of states in 
a world where the federal government is not taking 
action consistent with law to protect people and to 
save people money is even greater. And so we can and 
would expect to see action at the state level. The reversal comes at a time 
when the Trump administration is facing 
increasing political pressure to improve 
affordability, including lowering energy 
costs for consumers. With midterms approaching 
72% of Americans rate economic conditions as only 
fair or poor, and 51% of Americans say 
they are very concerned about the price of 
electricity, according to a Pew Research 
Center survey. So we have indicated that if 
the administration goes forward, as it has said it 
will, that we will plan to to file 
a legal challenge to this action. We don't think it 
will hold up in court. We do have a clear legal 
framework here. We have a law that Congress 
has passed, the Clean Air Act, 
that makes clear that EPA has the authority and 
responsibility to reduce this pollution, 
and the science is extremely clear here as well. Climate pollution hurts 
people's health and welfare. And there are solutions that 
we have to reduce this pollution, to make vehicles 
cleaner and to save people money. In September, 
a group of attorneys general from Democrat-led states 
wrote a comment letter opposing the repeal of the 
endangerment finding. I think it's important for 
people to understand how this really damaging action 
will impact Americans across the country in our lives. It will mean more pollution, and it will mean more 
pollution that forms smog, that exacerbates asthma, 
that leads to premature death. Our estimates suggest 
it could lead to up to 58,000 additional premature 
deaths by 2055, and we'll see higher costs 
that we're forced to pay at the gas pump and across our 
economy.

American Airlines has 
promised Wall Street and travelers that 2026 will be 
its turnaround year. It's been trailing its U.S. competitors, Delta Airlines 
and United Airlines in profits and reliability by a 
wide margin, and has fallen behind in the 
race for premium air travel. The customer experience is 
really what matters. And there is the issue goes 
back to basic tenets of what kind of business you want to 
run. And if you don't run a reliable business, 
you don't get repeat customers. American stock is down over 
the last 12 months, while other major U.S. 
airlines have posted gains. So the pressure is on for 
CEO Robert Isom. We were on track really like 
what we saw in October in terms of bookings on track 
to have a really solid turnaround in terms of our 
fourth quarter performance. Government shutdown hit us. 
It hit us harder than others. We're more 
domestically focused. We've seen bookings return 
first three weeks of this year, our best bookings on 
record. And as we come and take a 
look at this this year, 2026, we're returning to 
solid profitability. The airline flew a similar 
number of passengers and flights as its close 
competitors last year, but its profit was a tiny 
fraction of what United and Delta reported. Its net margins were 
significantly narrower too. 2025 started with a tragedy 
for American when an Army Blackhawk helicopter crashed 
into one of its arriving regional jets, 
killing all 67 people on the two aircraft. But American 
has trailed its competitors for several years. The slippage began decades 
ago, so it's nothing new. The issue really is the 
company deciding what it wants to be. I mean, 
it's a very, very basic issue. Does it want to be a global 
premium airline, full service in nature, 
or does it want to be a domestic volume oriented 
market price carrier? American has been lagging 
its rivals in the premium travel boom. It's a segment 
that's become more important because first class seats 
cost more and regular coach fares have slumped. Premium travel is a segment 
where the airline industry is seeing strength to catch 
up to rivals. American is now investing 
more heavily in premium products like new cabins. It plans to grow lie flat 
and premium economy seating by 50% by the end of the 
decade. It is also revamping its 
airport lounges, and it recently forged a new 
credit card deal with Citibank. It's even changing 
smaller things like adding Lavazza coffee and a new 
champagne brand. 321 XLR's are coming in. Really pleased with our 
Boeing 787-9 with the flagship suites. We've got lounge work going 
on throughout the system, and that's a cornerstone of 
what we're doing going forward. And this is not 
work that's just happening now. It's work that we've 
invested in and it's really coming to fruition now. American has also dropped 
below rivals in reliability, angering customers and crew 
members. It's much, much less 
expensive, much greater margin to do it 
right than to have to do it over. And ultimately, 
employees pay for that, too. American's pilot and flight 
attendant unions have called Isom's leadership into 
question. The flight attendants union 
went as far as passing a vote of no confidence in 
Isom, because American's profits 
were so low. Profit sharing with staff was also small, 
upsetting key labor groups. Isom acknowledged this, 
but did note, however, that American has 
recently passed new contracts with flight 
attendants and other labor groups that come with higher 
pay compared with their counterparts at United. Airline analysts say that 
change will take time and the carrier will have to 
spend money to get there. Another challenge is that 
American has to pay down more than $35 billion in 
debt. American put out an upbeat 
forecast for this year. It expects both revenue and 
profits to grow. Now, American's leadership 
will have to show it can improve financial results 
and the experience for passengers.

American tariffs have dealt 
a blow to Canadian auto manufacturing, and the

countries. Canada is dropping the 100%

from just a few years ago. Up until 2024, 
Canada had accepted Chinese vehicles of any kind at that 
same 6.1% tariff rate. But in 2024, following in 
the footsteps of the US, it raised the duty on 
Chinese EVs to effectively 106%. In exchange for 
reducing the duty, China said it would reduce

joint ventures between China and Canada that will 
generate jobs for Canadian workers and help build out 
the country's EV supply chain. Canada's auto 
manufacturing sector has been shrinking for about the

in 2000 to 1.3 million in 2025. The introduction of 
the US tariffs has accelerated the decline. China is not the only 
country Canada is striking deals with. It also signed a 
memorandum of understanding with Korea on clean vehicle 
manufacturing. In early February, 
the Canadian government released a new automotive 
strategy for the country. It restored the $5,000 
federal credit for electric vehicles, which had run out 
of money in 2025. The government also plans to 
offer tax credits for manufacturers in the 
country. But experts say that if 
Canada's relationship with the US doesn't improve, 
it's unclear if international automakers are 
going to want to invest in a country when it doesn't have 
access to the US market. Domestic car sales in Canada 
are only 1.8 to 2 million units a year. New car sales 
in the US are about eight times that. Canada exports 
around 90% of the vehicles it makes overwhelmingly to 
the US, and imports make up about 
the same percentage of vehicles sold in the 
country. Under the agreement, 
49,000 Chinese EVs are permitted in Canada. Initially, that number could 
rise to 70,000 in 5 years. Even if one Chinese 
automaker were to totally monopolize that, 
it still wouldn't be enough to justify the construction 
of a typical factory. The high fixed costs of 
manufacturing require that a plant make a minimum of 
200,000 to 250,000 vehicles to be profitable. Given that the Canadian 
government is likely to allocate shares of the total 
49,000 to different automakers, each one might 
only sell, say, 15,000. That would 
leave a factory with a huge balance of EVs. It would be forced to sell 
somewhere else. Where are they going to go? 
They're not going to go to the US. Maybe they're going 
to go to Europe. Maybe they're going to go to 
the UK. Maybe they're going to go to Mexico, 
or maybe they're going to have a global mandate, 
or maybe they won't do this at all. Officially, the US policy is 
a 25% tariff on non-U.S. content on cars imported 
from Canada. Effectively, that works out 
to about a 10 to 12% duty on each car. It's impossible to 
overstate how integrated Canada, the US and Mexico 
were up until the Trump administration began levying 
tariffs. Researchers say that a 
single part, such as an engine or 
transmission, can cross these borders 7 or 
8 times. But its decision to allow 
Chinese EVs has led President Trump to threaten 
a 100% tariff on all Canadian goods and services. Canada's deal with China 
will be a vehicle sized irritant on trade talks with 
the US, said the head of the group 
that represents Detroit automakers in the country. 
American manufacturers make up only about 23% of 
Canadian auto production. Japanese makers Toyota and 
Honda make up the other 77%. Brian Kingston, 
who is head of the group that represents GM, 
Ford and Stellantis, told me that there are 
several reasons for this decline. The cyclical nature 
of the auto industry, the disruptions from the 
trade talks, the retooling of plants for 
EVs. Kingston told me that Canada 
has everything the US needs to pivot away from China, 
including every critical mineral needed for a next 
generation EV. It also has hydroelectric 
and nuclear power for factories.

videos.transcript:
[Chip Roy] Under the SAVE 
America Act, individuals will be required to provide 
that proof of citizenship in order to register and on 
Election day, required to demonstrate 
voter identification. The purpose of the SAVE act 
is to ban non-citizens from voting in federal elections, 
and also to implement some kind of voter ID law where 
you would have to show your driver's license when you go 
to cast a ballot. My name is Justin Papp. I 
cover politics for CNBC. So the initial version of 
the SAVE act that Chip Roy introduced and Mike Lee 
introduced in the Senate in late January, 
would have required some form of ID at the ballot box 
that proved you were an American citizen. So something like a 
passport, for instance. There was an 
amended version of the SAVE act that was introduced over 
the weekend that pairs that back a little bit. Some form of photo ID would 
still be required at the polls to vote, 
but the list of acceptable forms of ID is longer and 
could include things like state issued IDs. Importantly, college IDs are 
still prohibited under this amended version, 
which is a concern that many Democrats have that 
Republicans are specifically targeting demographic 
groups, including young people that 
tend to vote for Democrats. [Chuck Schumer] While the 
specific policies may have changed since the days of 
the Jim Crow South, the goal of the Save act is 
the same disenfranchising American citizens and making 
it harder for eligible people to vote. More than 21 million 
Americans don't have ready access to documents proving 
that they're American citizens, and something like 
more than 2 million people don't have a valid form of 
government issued ID. Such as things like voter ID 
have become more of a concern, particularly among 
Republicans. Some states, mostly in the 
South, like North Carolina and 
Mississippi, have implemented voter ID laws. Non-citizens are not allowed 
to vote in federal elections. But there are 
certain territories like Washington, D.C. that allow 
them to vote. Elections are mostly state 
run. States can decide their own 
laws around how they carry out elections. But 
constitutionally, Congress does have a role in 
legislating around how elections are carried out. [Donald Trump] You know, 
if you think about it, a state is an agent for the 
federal government and elections. I don't know why 
the federal government doesn't do them anyway. Trump just keeps banging 
this drum about the prospect of non-citizens voting, 
and it sort of reached a fever pitch in the past 
several weeks. He's raised concerns about 
the security of elections and about the prospect of 
non-citizens voting in elections. It can happen. It does happen occasionally, but it is already illegal. And there are strict 
penalties for anybody who tries to vote if they're a 
non-citizen. Fundamentally, most 
Democrats do not agree with the concept of voter I.D., 
and so it's got a very difficult path to get to 
President Trump's desk. The Republican majority in 
the Senate is slim. More than a handful of 
Democrats would have to join their Republican colleagues 
and support the bill to get it over the 60 vote 
filibuster threshold. My sense is they're trying 
to make this proposal more palatable to Democrats. There's been this massive 
pressure campaign from the GOP, from influencers, 
from people like Elon Musk. In addition to Trump 
himself, they continue to point to 
public polling, which shows that the vast 
majority of Americans are in support of at least the 
concept of voter I.D.. But Democrats and voting 
rights groups say the devil is in the details. It's 
about how those voting rights laws are written and 
who they will potentially disenfranchise.

videos.title: What's Stopping GLP-1s From Getting Cheaper

The push to make weight loss drugs more affordable is running into legal limits. Telehealth company Hims & Hers pulled a less expensive oral version of Wegovy after lawsuits from Novo Nordisk and rising regulatory scrutiny. videos.transcript:
The race to offer cheaper 
weight loss drugs is running into some legal limits. Telehealth company Hims & 
Hers announced a cheaper version of Novo's Wegovy 
weight-loss pill at the beginning of February. Now it would cost $49 to 
start, which is far less than the 
$149 Novo sells the branded pill for. But it pulled the 
drug after legal and regulatory risks escalated. Now, legally, 
they're allowed to create a compounded version of a drug 
if they are saying they're adjusting the formula for 
"personalized purposes." A legitimate example would be 
to mitigate side effects for patients by lowering 
commercially available dosages. But Novo announced 
it will sue Hims over patent infringement. Novo argues 
those compounded versions are no longer justified 
because semaglutide is no longer in a shortage in the 
U.S. Novo also says Hims crossed 
the line from individualized compounding into what it 
calls illegal mass compounding, producing 
standardized versions at scale under the label of 
personalization. Now, this is one of over 130 
federal lawsuits that have been filed by Novo Nordisk 
nationwide targeting pharmacies, telehealth 
companies, and others. Hims responded 
to Novo's complaint, writing on X this lawsuit 
attacks more than just one medication or company. It directly assaults a 
well-established, vital component of U.S. pharmacy practice that has 
improved patient care for everything from obesity to 
infertility to cancer. On top of that, 
FDA Commissioner Marty Makary has weighed in on the 
dispute. He wrote on X, 
the office will take action against mass marketing of 
drugs that claim to be the same as the branded FDA 
approved drugs, and the FDA has also 
signaled it could escalate enforcement, including 
restricting access to key ingredients and referring 
potential violations to the Department of Justice. If you're in the market of 
providing health care solutions to the public, 
do so in a transparent way that the American public can 
rely upon. If you don't do that, 
we're watching and we will make referrals as 
appropriate. The catch is, 
legal grounds remain unclear to come after Hims directly 
on that basis alone, an FDA crackdown sounds like 
regulators are about to shut down compounding altogether. But like I said, 
compounding itself is legal and necessary when it's done 
for individualized patient needs. Of course, 
Hims and hers isn't the only telehealth provider in the 
game. Ro is one example that folks have referenced as the 
good actor in this case. They've actually been 
transitioning a lot of patients from those early 
compounded drugs when there was a drug shortage, 
to the branded drugs like what Novo Nordisk offers 
with Wegovy and Ozempic. Compounding pharmacies are a 
small but visible part of the weight-loss drug market, valued at nearly $7 billion 
in 2025. They don't threaten Big 
Pharma's core sales, but regulators could limit 
their ability to scale and market these drugs going 
forward. Novo estimates as many as 
1.5 million Americans are currently using compounded 
GLP-1 drugs, and the FDA's focus then 
turns to marketing, not compounding. Specifically, mass 
advertising that makes compounded drugs sound 
interchangeable with FDA approved products like 
Wegovy. And that's why the FDA is 
warning language has been careful. They're signaling 
enforcement around claims, not automatically around the 
pharmacies or facilities making these drugs. This puts companies like 
Hims in a tricky spot. The drug may be compounded 
at FDA registered facilities, but aggressive 
marketing opens the door to regulatory action, 
and markets reacted to that uncertainty, with Hims stock 
declining on Monday after they pulled the oral version 
of the compound. These GLP-1 drugs can be big 
moneymakers considering the demand, but the complicated 
web of regulations surrounding them may be 
prohibitive for companies trying to lower the price. And investors, 
well, they're starting to take notice.
